thread.title: Mohamed Elneny's return is just what Arsene Wenger needs to steady rocking Arsenal
thread.title_full: Mohamed Elneny's return is just what Arsene Wenger needs to steady rocking Arsenal

author: james olley
title: Mohamed Elneny's return is just what Arsene Wenger needs to steady rocking Arsenal
text:
Tuesday 7 February 2017 12:48 GMT Click to followES Sport Heaven sent: Mohamed Elneny is back after playing for Egypt in the Africa Cup of Nations Issouf SanogoAFP/Getty Images 
When Mohamed Elneny left for the Africa Cup of Nations on January 2, Arsenal had just beaten Crystal Palace 2-0, with Olivier Giroud’s scorpion-kick goal the talk of football. 
The Gunners were still nine points behind leaders Chelsea but, with an inviting run of fixtures ahead, there was still a belief that Arsene Wenger’s side could have a meaningful say in the Premier League title race. 
Elneny returns this week to find his team-mates in a more sombre mood. Successive defeats to Watford and Chelsea have left Arsenal 12 points off the pace and facing a perennial scramble to remain in the top four. 
The 24-year-old will return to London Colney for assessment tomorrow to determine whether he is ready to return to the starting line-up against Hull on Saturday. Central midfield reinforcements are badly needed. Neville has 'overstepped mark' with attack on fans, say Arsenal Fan TV 
Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain produced a few bright moments at Stamford Bridge but it was not a convincing audition for an extended run in the middle of the pitch, as he craves. 
Hull do not possess Chelsea’s power, but the sight of Oxlade-Chamberlain and Francis Coquelin being overwhelmed at times by Antonio Conte’s side will surely force Wenger to look elsewhere, especially with next Wednesday’s Champions League last-16, first-leg clash at Bayern Munich in mind. Frederic Mendy (L) of Guinea Bissau goes for a header against Aaron Appindangoye of Gabon during the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations match between Gabon and Guinea Bissau at the Libreville Stadium in Gabon EPA 51/55

Performance during the opening ceremony of the Africa Nations Cup at the Stade de l'Amitie, Libreville, Gabon AP 55/55 
A performer dressed as Samba, the mascot of the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations football tournament, dances during the opening ceremony at the Stade de l'Amitie Sino-Gabonaise in Libreville AFP/Getty Images 
More urgency is required. Statistics show Arsenal have been outrun in their last nine League matches, averaging nearly three miles fewer than their opponents. 
Arsenal tend to dominate possession, so those figures have a notable caveat, but there is a need to inject some fresh dynamism. 
Elneny is understood to have suffered no ill effects from a quick return to action in Sunday’s final against Cameroon following a calf injury sustained earlier in the competition. Mentally, he might need a little longer to move on. He scored the opening goal but saw Egypt concede an 88th-minute winner. Premier League standings after 24 matches 
The biggest problem created by Santi Cazorla’s ongoing absence is a lack of quick forward distribution from midfield and the more pedestrian the pace in Arsenal’s passing, the less effective Mesut Ozil, Alexis Sanchez and Theo Walcott become. 
Elneny has not been an unqualified success since his £7million move from Basel just over a year ago, but with Aaron Ramsey sidelined with a calf problem, Cazorla several weeks away from returning, Jack Wilshere away on loan and Granit Xhaka serving the last game of a four-match ban, his return is a welcome sight. 
Elneny gave an interview during his time away in which he claimed he wants to become an Arsenal “legend”. Now would be a perfect time to start building that legacy. More about:
